reviewText: After the legendary Weissmuller series of Tarzan films and the competent outings by Lex Barker, ignoring the mis-fires along the way, it was time for a new Tarzan... In stepped Gordon Scott; all 6'3" of him! In this first outing in the role he adopts the monosyllabic take on Tarzan, made famous by Weissmuller, and does an admiral job. He looked the part and moved well but, at this stage, his acting was almost as wooden as the trees in the jungle! Scott would later go on to make what many consider to be 2 of the finest Tarzan films of all, so there was redemption after this shaky start. The flimsy plot and daft script keep this adventure safely in the second division of Tarzan films, although it is not without merit. The film deserves a solid 3 stars as it is well filmed with thoughtfully edited in stock footage. The warner archives CD-R is taken from a very good print and I cannot imagine the film ever looking better. Worth adding to your Tarzan collection but not one of the series highlights.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is the first of Gordon Scott's Tarzan movie's and it does not disappoint even though it is in black and white.  A group hunters are out to find game and found them in an area that is off limits to hunters.  This does not stop them and they try to drive the animals over across the river where it is legal to hunt. Tarzan is out to stop them and rescue a doctor that got caught up in their scheme.  The doctor's nurse who comes along with Tarzan to save the doctor is Vera Miles, who later becomes the real Mrs. Tarzan or Mrs. Gordon Scott.  In my opinion Gordon Scott is the best of all Tarzans.  If you like Tarzan then you will enjoy this film.  GLS
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is Gordon Scott's first movie as Tarzan. He succeeded Les Barker who followed Johnny Weissmuller. Scott was so successful that he continued five more times as Tarzan. Most Tarzan films follow a similar plot, and this one is no exception. Several hunters try to kill animals so that they can sell their furs, oils, tusks, and other body parts. Tarzan saves the animals in his area. The hunters decide to kill animals in another area where the animals are protected by natives who kill anyone who harms them. In some Tarzan films, whites play natives, but in this film they are black. Cheetah, as usual, adds comic relief. Generally, a woman, usually Jane, persuades Tarzan to do something that is inadvisable. This film is similar: a nurse persuades a doctor to take the hunters with him to the area protected by the natives. Tarzan needs to save the white people and he does so, as expected, with his Tarzan yell, which summons the elephants. Despite the marked similarities with previous Tarzan films, this movie is fun to watch.
summary: Gordon Scott's debut as Tarzan was successful with his fans
Title: N/A

reviewText: Scott's first Tarzan film is fairly typical for the genre. Two hunters lie to a doctor and tell him they work for the United Nations so they can get to a forbidden area that is ripe for hunting. Hunting though is banned by the natives and when the hunters try killing the animals the natives blame the doctor and Tarzan has to save him and his assistant played by Vera Miles from being thrown to the lions.  Scott is pretty good in his first outing and looks great. He really grew into the role and made it his own in the last Tarzan movies he did, particularly "Tarzan's Greatest Adventure" and 'Tarzan the Magnificent" that are not only two of the best Tarzan films ever made but two great adventure films of any kind. It's a shame that the producer of the series let Scott go. If he had been able to do even one or two more he might have eclipsed Johnny Weissmuller as the greatest Tarzan of them all. It is interesting to see him grow and mature into the role. Also in the last two films he made his character finally talks full english.
summary: Gordon Scott's First Tarzan and Definitely Worth Watching

reviewText: This outing of Tarzan was the last RKO produced film on this character.  Gordon Scott was introduced as the new Tarzan in this film.  Again color would have helped this movie but even in black and white this was a very good production.
